awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track B: Legacy Building Toolset
awd_abstract_narration:
The Legacy Building Toolset (LBT) is a digital platform, centered on interactive data visualizations, that allows community members to collectively explore identity, the meaning of place, and create and engage with community assets. Currently such tools and methods are underexplored, which is concerning because public policy is often based on how policymakers perceive the meaning of place from the perspective of residents. As a result, residents often find it challenging to collect and organize community information to present to policy makers or face exclusion when their interpretations of the built form remain unrecognized. The LBT aims to realize community-accessible tools for creating community-driven interpretations of meaning in the built form at a large scale, in real time, and with an overlay of culture and identity. The tool will be developed in Northeast Oklahoma City, a disadvantaged and predominantly Black community, and the knowledge gained will be disseminated for use by other communities across the United States. 

The development and deployment of the Legacy Building Toolset (LBT) through the envisioned Stage 2 pilot project will combine successful engagement methods of photovoice and storytelling with scalability via crowdsourced data editing and viewing directly inside maps, timelines, and other data visualizations. The LBT will include a collection of intuitively interactive, visualization-centric, in-browser data editing and viewing applications supported by a web services database backend. The applications will support entry of information about people, places, times, and other details through interactive gesturing directly in the visualizations themselves. This includes opportunities to annotate locations, regions, and times with photos, video, or audio. The applications will also support organization of information into stories that integrate text, visualizations, and multimedia annotations. Existing photovoice and storytelling methods often require an in-person expert who organizes and leads the process. Through visualization-centric user interfaces, the LBT will provide less centralized methods of collecting, organizing, and curating community information. The community will be able to develop and use stories more independently of experts. Many urban design and planning projects may still benefit from or even require expert involvement, but the community will be able to identify needs through the LBT and call upon experts internal or external to the community as needed. The broader impacts will be to make participation in community collaboration projects involving sharing of data more accessible, usable, and scalable, especially in historically disadvantaged communities, and broaden the user base for both data sharing and projects built on it. 

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track B. Bridging the gap between essential resources and services & community needs—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The Legacy Building Toolset project explores how residents of underserved and/or marginalized neighborhoods interpret the built form, create and engage with community assets, and make meaning of urban space. These questions are unfortunately underexplored. This is especially concerning given that public policy from urban planning to social services are often based on how policy makers perceive the meaning of place from the perspective of residents. As a result, residents often experience powerlessness, the exclusion of their voices being heard, and policy that does not reflect community interpretations.  This project was a planning project to create the framework for the goals, scope, and partners necessary to develop and implement a digital community building tool called the Legacy Building toolset (LBT). 

The Legacy Building Toolset is designed to create community-driven interpretations of meaning in the built form at a large scale, in real time, and which is rooted in culture and identity. While the toolset is being considered within the specific urban context of Northeast Oklahoma City, the knowledge gained from implementation could be replicable to cities across the US.

We designed the buildout and deployment of the Legacy Building Toolset to go beyond the state-of-practice and state-of-the-art community collaboration methods by combining the scalability of data visualization with the successful engagement methods of photovoice and storytelling. These methods often require an in-person expert to organize and lead the process, synthesize information, and report results. The LBT could provide less centralized methods of organizing and curating information via web accessible visualization tools. This would allow the community to self-organize the process and curate information independently or alongside experts. Urban design and planning projects may still benefit from expertise, but the community would be able to identify needs through the toolset and call upon experts internal or external to the community to facilitate information collection and curation, enabling and encouraging broader participation in community collaboration projects.

The Legacy Building Toolset is designed to be an example for community-led city planning and community building. The toolset would allow NEOKC to benefit from having centralized information that is accessible to community members and builds over time. The history of the erased neighborhoods would be able to inform future development and a neighborhood legacy would be protected and developed. The information on the platform may inform transportation and mobility improvement projects, cultural programming, and resources for establishing city recognized commercial districts. The toolset could be applicable to other neighborhoods within OKC or elsewhere to inform projects critical to their identity and development. The framework for the LBT can serve as an example of practical tools and scalable visual data editing features which can motivate similar applications as well as extend knowledge of interaction design for researchers and practitioners in the visualization community.

 


Last Modified: 07/27/2023
Modified by: Deborah Richards
